metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: ¹H-NMR for proton environments, integration ratios, and n+1 splitting rule

h1-nmr-basics.name: ¹H-NMR Basics
h1-nmr-basics.correct: ¹H-NMR detects hydrogen nuclei (protons) in different chemical environments

detects all hydrogen isotopes equally.error: Not recognising ¹H specificity - ¹H-NMR is specific to protium
detects all hydrogen isotopes equally.fix: ¹H-NMR specifically detects protium (¹H); deuterium (²H) is not detected
detects all hydrogen isotopes equally.action: Deuterated solvents (like CDCl₃) don't interfere because ²H is NMR-silent

detects carbon atoms.fix: ¹H-NMR detects hydrogen nuclei; ¹³C-NMR detects carbon-13 nuclei
detects carbon atoms.action: Match nucleus to technique: ¹H-NMR = protons, ¹³C-NMR = carbons

uses infrared radiation.fix: NMR uses radio waves in a magnetic field; IR uses infrared radiation
uses infrared radiation.action: Remember: NMR = radio waves + magnet; IR = infrared absorption

persistent.gap: Not understanding ¹H-NMR specifically detects proton environments
persistent.action: Focus on ¹H-NMR revealing number, type, and ratio of proton environments

proton-equivalence.name: Proton Equivalence
proton-equivalence.correct: Equivalent protons in identical chemical environments produce one peak

each hydrogen gives a separate peak.fix: Hydrogens in identical environments are equivalent and give one signal
each hydrogen gives a separate peak.action: Use molecular symmetry to identify equivalent protons

only adjacent protons are equivalent.fix: Equivalence depends on chemical environment, not just position
only adjacent protons are equivalent.action: All three H in a CH₃ group are equivalent if the group has free rotation

number of peaks equals number of hydroge.error: Confusing total H with unique environments
number of peaks equals number of hydroge.fix: Peaks = unique proton environments, often less than total H count
number of peaks equals number of hydroge.action: Ethane (C₂H₆) shows 1 peak because all 6 H are equivalent

persistent.gap: Not identifying equivalent protons using symmetry
persistent.action: Look for symmetry planes and rotation axes to find equivalent protons

chemical-shift-h.name: Proton Chemical Shift
chemical-shift-h.correct: Proton chemical shift in ppm indicates shielding, with TMS at 0 ppm

TMS protons appear at 10 ppm.error: Wrong reference position - TMS defines 0 ppm
TMS protons appear at 10 ppm.fix: TMS is the reference at 0 ppm; most organic protons appear 0-12 ppm
TMS protons appear at 10 ppm.action: TMS = 0 ppm; higher δ = more deshielded

higher shift means more shielded.fix: Higher chemical shift (δ) means less shielded (more deshielded)
higher shift means more shielded.action: Deshielded = downfield = higher δ; shielded = upfield = lower δ

measured in cm⁻¹.fix: ¹H-NMR uses ppm (parts per million); cm⁻¹ is for IR spectroscopy

persistent.gap: Not understanding chemical shift scale in ¹H-NMR
persistent.action: ¹H range typically 0-12 ppm; alkyl ~0-2, aromatic ~6-8, aldehyde ~9-10 ppm

integration.name: Integration
integration.correct: Integration curve height is proportional to the number of protons in that environment

peak height indicates proton count.fix: Integration (area under peak) indicates relative proton numbers, not peak height
peak height indicates proton count.action: Look at integration trace/values, not peak heights

gives exact number of protons.error: Not recognising ratios vs absolute numbers
gives exact number of protons.fix: Integration gives ratios of protons; combine with molecular formula for actual numbers
gives exact number of protons.action: A 3:2 integration ratio could be 3H:2H or 6H:4H depending on the molecule

works the same as in ¹³C-NMR.fix: ¹H-NMR integration is reliable; ¹³C-NMR integration is not quantitative
works the same as in ¹³C-NMR.action: Only trust integration in ¹H-NMR, not ¹³C-NMR

persistent.gap: Not using integration to determine proton ratios
persistent.action: Calculate integration ratios and match to expected proton counts

n-plus-one-rule.name: n+1 Rule
n-plus-one-rule.correct: A proton signal splits into n+1 peaks where n is the number of neighbouring non-equivalent protons

n is total protons in molecule.fix: n = number of non-equivalent protons on adjacent carbons only
n is total protons in molecule.action: Only count protons on neighbouring carbons that are not equivalent to the observed protons

splitting depends on the proton being ob.fix: Splitting is caused by neighbouring protons, not by the protons giving the signal
splitting depends on the proton being ob.action: A CH₃ next to CH₂ gives a triplet because of the 2 neighbouring protons

equivalent protons split each other.error: Not understanding equivalent protons don't cause splitting
equivalent protons split each other.fix: Equivalent protons do not split each other; only non-equivalent neighbours cause splitting
equivalent protons split each other.action: The 3 H in a CH₃ don't split each other but do split neighbouring protons

persistent.gap: Not correctly applying the n+1 rule for splitting patterns
persistent.action: Count H on adjacent carbons (n), then add 1 for multiplicity

splitting-patterns.name: Splitting Patterns
splitting-patterns.correct: Singlet (1), doublet (2), triplet (3), quartet (4) indicate 0, 1, 2, 3 neighbouring protons

singlet means one proton.fix: Singlet means 0 neighbouring non-equivalent protons, not 1 proton total
singlet means one proton.action: A CH₃ group with no neighbours gives a singlet (could be 3H integration)

quartet means four protons in the group.fix: Quartet means 3 neighbouring protons (n=3, n+1=4 peaks)
quartet means four protons in the group.action: A CH₂ next to CH₃ appears as a quartet because of 3 neighbouring H

triplet means the proton is on carbon 3.error: Confusing pattern name with carbon position
triplet means the proton is on carbon 3.action: Pattern names indicate peak count: triplet = 3 peaks from 2 neighbours

persistent.gap: Not relating splitting pattern to neighbour count
persistent.action: Memorise: singlet (0), doublet (1), triplet (2), quartet (3) neighbours

coupling-constant.name: Coupling Constant
coupling-constant.correct: The coupling constant (J) in Hz measures the spacing between split peaks

J is measured in ppm.fix: Coupling constant J is measured in Hz, not ppm
J is measured in ppm.action: Chemical shift = ppm; Coupling constant = Hz

J depends on spectrometer frequency.fix: J in Hz is independent of spectrometer frequency (unlike chemical shift in Hz)
J depends on spectrometer frequency.action: J values are constant regardless of spectrometer field strength

coupled peaks have different J values.fix: Mutually coupled protons show the same J value in their splitting
coupled peaks have different J values.action: If Ha splits Hb with J=7 Hz, then Hb splits Ha with J=7 Hz too

persistent.gap: Not understanding coupling constant as peak spacing in Hz
persistent.action: J value connects related multiplets - look for matching spacings

spectrum-analysis-h.name: ¹H Spectrum Analysis
spectrum-analysis-h.correct: Analyse ¹H-NMR by checking chemical shift, integration, and splitting pattern for each peak

only check chemical shift.error: Incomplete analysis - missing integration and splitting
only check chemical shift.fix: Full ¹H-NMR analysis uses all three: chemical shift, integration, and splitting
only check chemical shift.action: For each signal: Where? (δ), How many? (integration), What neighbours? (splitting)

start analysis with splitting patterns.fix: Often best to start with integration to identify likely groups, then splitting and shift
start analysis with splitting patterns.action: Integration identifies groups (CH₃=3H, CH₂=2H), then confirm with splitting

ignore peaks near 0 ppm.error: May miss TMS or highly shielded protons
ignore peaks near 0 ppm.fix: Check all peaks including near 0 ppm for alkyl groups or TMS reference
ignore peaks near 0 ppm.action: TMS appears at 0 ppm; alkyl groups often 0-2 ppm

persistent.gap: Not using systematic analysis of all three ¹H-NMR parameters
persistent.action: For every peak: note δ (type), integration (count), splitting (neighbours)

sentences.text: ¹H-NMR spectroscopy detects {{d1}} nuclei (protons) when placed in a {{d2}} field and exposed to {{d3}} radiation.

d2.tooltip: NMR requires a strong magnetic field

sentences.text: Protons in identical chemical environments are called {{d1}} protons and produce {{d2}} signal in the spectrum.

d2.tooltip: Equivalent protons give a single peak

sentences.text: Chemical shift in ¹H-NMR is measured in {{d1}} with {{d2}} as the reference at {{d3}} ppm.

d1.tooltip: Chemical shift uses parts per million (ppm)

sentences.text: The {{d1}} of a peak in ¹H-NMR is proportional to the {{d2}} of protons in that environment.

d2.tooltip: Integration is proportional to proton count

sentences.text: Integration values give {{d1}} of protons, not absolute numbers. A ratio of 3:2 could represent {{d2}} and {{d3}} protons.

d3.tooltip: Or could be 6H:4H in larger molecule

sentences.text: Unlike ¹³C-NMR, integration in ¹H-NMR is {{d1}} for determining proton ratios because all protons have similar {{d2}} times.
The n+1 rule states that a proton signal splits into {{d1}} peaks when there are n {{d2}} protons on {{d3}} carbons.

d3.tooltip: Only protons on neighbouring carbons cause splitting

sentences.text: A singlet has {{d1}} neighbour(s), a doublet has {{d2}} neighbour(s), and a triplet has {{d3}} neighbour(s).
The spacing between split peaks is called the {{d1}} constant, measured in {{d2}}, and has the same value for {{d3}} coupled protons.

d3.tooltip: Coupled pairs share the same J value

sentences.text: A chemist analyses ethanol (CH₃CH₂OH). The ¹H-NMR shows {{d1}} distinct signals because there are {{d2}} different proton environments: the {{d3}} protons, the CH₂ protons, and the OH proton.

d2.tooltip: CH₃, CH₂, and OH are different environments

d3.tooltip: The three methyl protons are equivalent

sentences.text: Propanone (CH₃COCH₃) shows only {{d1}} signal(s) in its ¹H-NMR because the molecule has {{d2}} that makes both methyl groups {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: All 6 protons in propanone are equivalent

d3.tooltip: Both CH₃ groups are identical environments

sentences.text: Protons near electronegative atoms like oxygen appear at {{d1}} chemical shift because they are {{d2}}. An aldehyde proton (CHO) typically appears around {{d3}} ppm.
An unknown compound shows two peaks with integration ratio 3:2. If the molecular formula is C₃H₈O, this suggests one {{d1}} group (3H) and one {{d2}} group (2H), consistent with {{d3}}.
The ¹H-NMR of propan-1-ol shows three signals with integration ratio approximately {{d1}}:{{d2}}:{{d3}}. The largest integration corresponds to the {{d4}} group.
To convert integration ratios to actual proton numbers, compare the total from the {{d1}} to the integration {{d2}}. Then scale each ratio accordingly.

d1.tooltip: Molecular formula gives total H count

sentences.text: In the ¹H-NMR of ethyl ethanoate (CH₃COOCH₂CH₃), the CH₂ group appears as a {{d1}} because it has {{d2}} neighbouring protons on the adjacent {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: The ethyl CH₃ is next to CH₂

sentences.text: The CH₃ group attached to the ethyl chain in ethyl ethanoate appears as a {{d1}} because it has {{d2}} neighbouring proton(s). The acetyl CH₃ (on C=O) appears as a {{d3}} because it has no adjacent protons.
A quartet and triplet with the same J value of 7 Hz are {{d1}}. This pattern is characteristic of an {{d2}} group (CH₃CH₂-) in the molecule.

d2.tooltip: Quartet + triplet is characteristic of ethyl

sentences.text: A student analyses an unknown alcohol. The ¹H-NMR shows peaks at δ 0.9 ppm (3H), 1.6 ppm (2H), 3.6 ppm (2H), and 2.5 ppm (1H). The peak at {{d1}} ppm corresponds to an {{d2}} group, while the peak at {{d3}} ppm is likely the CH₂ attached to {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: CH₂ next to O appears ~3.6 ppm

sentences.text: Para-xylene (1,4-dimethylbenzene) shows only {{d1}} signal(s) in its ¹H-NMR: one for the equivalent {{d2}} protons at ~{{d3}} ppm and one for the equivalent CH₃ protons at ~2.3 ppm.

d1.tooltip: Two environments: aromatic H and CH₃

d2.tooltip: All 4 aromatic H are equivalent by symmetry

sentences.text: An unknown ester C₄H₈O₂ shows three signals with integration 3:3:2. The two peaks with integration {{d1}} suggest two {{d2}} groups, while integration {{d3}} suggests one {{d4}} group. Combined with the splitting patterns, this helps identify the compound.

Distinguishing propan-1-ol from propan-2-ol by ¹H-NMR: propan-1-ol shows {{d1}} signals with integration {{d2}}, while propan-2-ol shows {{d3}} signals with integration {{d4}} due to molecular {{d5}}.

To fully analyse a ¹H-NMR spectrum, consider all three parameters: {{d1}} indicates environment type, {{d2}} indicates proton count, and {{d3}} indicates neighbouring protons. For the CH₃ in ethanol, these would be δ ~{{d4}} ppm, integration {{d5}}, and a {{d6}} pattern.

d6.tooltip: CH₃ next to CH₂ gives triplet

sentences.text: An unknown compound shows: δ 1.1 ppm (triplet, 3H), δ 2.3 ppm (quartet, 2H), and δ 9.8 ppm (singlet, 1H). The triplet-quartet pattern indicates an {{d1}} group. The singlet at {{d2}} ppm with integration {{d3}} indicates an {{d4}} proton. The compound is likely {{d5}}.

explanations.h1-nmr-basics: ¹H-NMR detects protons in different chemical environments using radio waves in a magnetic field.
explanations.proton-equivalence: Equivalent protons in identical environments give one signal; molecular symmetry creates equivalence.
explanations.chemical-shift-h: Proton chemical shift (δ) in ppm indicates shielding; TMS=0 ppm, alkyl ~1, aromatic ~7, aldehyde ~10 ppm.
explanations.integration: Integration is proportional to proton count; gives ratios that can be scaled using the molecular formula.
explanations.n-plus-one-rule: A signal splits into n+1 peaks where n = number of non-equivalent protons on adjacent carbons.
explanations.splitting-patterns: Singlet (0), doublet (1), triplet (2), quartet (3) neighbours; pattern names indicate peak count.
explanations.coupling-constant: Coupling constant (J) in Hz measures peak spacing; mutually coupled protons share the same J value.
explanations.spectrum-analysis-h: Full ¹H-NMR analysis uses chemical shift (type), integration (count), and splitting (neighbours) together.
